title: Gothic Y - No Old English but what?
content:
Most people think this is Old English, but this specific “Y” doesn’t appear that way in Old English. Any specific suggestions?

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [File](http://web.archive.org/system/files?file=drupal_11) | 18.88 KB |
author: barrycards

comments.content: i think it’s safe to say it’s custom.

Is this a logo for a sports team? If so, it was most likely custom designed. You can get close with something like [Archive Black Title](http://web.archive.org/web/20051111093914/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/archivetype/archive-black-title/), [Baroque Text JF](http://web.archive.org/web/20051111093914/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/jawfonts/baroque-text-jf/) or [Crusader](http://web.archive.org/web/20051111093914/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontdetail&displayfontid=C.100780.0.0&attributes.sampleSize=48&sampleText=Y&sampleSize=48&attributes.paraSize=14&paraSize=14).

- Lex

P.S. To the forum admins: What’s all this “drupal” business?

- Lex
Drupal is the name of the software on which Typophile is based. For some reason the uploaded images are now defaulting to that name.
Why am I always the last moderator to know about these things!? :)

The New York Times as a Y somewhat similar - but with the descender reversed.  
 [http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/section/homepage/NYT\_home\_banner.gif](http://web.archive.org/web/20051111093914/http:/graphics8.nytimes.com/images/section/homepage/NYT_home_banner.gif)
